title: Do the pairs represent a function?
text: Think about the condition that makes some $$x-y$$ pairs a function.
speech: Think about the condition that makes some  x minus y  pairs a function.
pacedSpeech: Think about the condition that makes some   x minus y

title: If pairs represent a function, each x-value is matched with only one y-value.
text: So, are the pairs in this question a function?
speech: So, are the pairs in this question a function?
pacedSpeech: So, are the pairs in this question a function?

title: Do the pairs represent a one-to-one function?
text: A function is one-to-one if each value in the range corresponds to one element in the domain. For each ordered pair in the function, each y-value is matched with only one x-value. There are no repeated y-values.
speech: A function is one-to-one if each value in the range corresponds to one element in the domain. For each ordered pair in the function, each y-value is matched with only one x-value. There are no repeated y-values.
pacedSpeech: A function is one-to-one if each value in the range corresponds to one element in the domain. For each ordered pair in the function, each y-value is matched with only one x-value. There are no repeated y-values.

title: Determine if it is one-to-one
text: Is there a $$y$$ value that has more than one $$x$$ paired with that $$y$$?
speech: Is there a , y  value that has more than one  x  paired with that  y, ?
pacedSpeech: value that has more than one   x
